name.text: Find several x-values on the graph of the trigonometric function y=f(x)=tan(x) or y=cos(x) or y=sin(x)

questiontext.text:
Consider the graph of the trigonometric function \(y=f(x)={@fx@}\) and the point on the graph at an angle \(x = {@angdeg@}\).

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-3 * Math.PI - 1, 3, 4 * Math.PI + 1, -3], keepaspectratio: false, showCopyright: false, pan: false }); var f = board.jc.snippet('{#fx#}', true, 'x', true); board.create('functiongraph', [f, -3 * Math.PI - 1, 4 * Math.PI + 1]); var xaxis = board.create('axis', [ [0, 0], [1, 0] ]); xaxis.removeAllTicks(); board.create('ticks', [xaxis, Math.PI/4], { strokeColor: '#ccc', majorHeight: -1, minorTicks: 1, drawZero: false }); var yaxis = board.create('axis', [ [0, 0], [0, 1] ]); yaxis.removeAllTicks(); board.create('ticks', [yaxis, 1], { strokeColor: '#ccc', majorHeight: -1, drawLabels: true, label: { offset: [7, -2] }, minorTicks: 1, drawZero: false }); var txt = board.create('text', [Math.PI - 0.5, -0.2, "180"], { fontSize: 15, fixed: true }); var txt = board.create('text', [2 * Math.PI - 0.5, -0.2, "360"], { fontSize: 15, fixed: true }); var txt = board.create('text', [3 * Math.PI - 0.5, -0.2, "540"], { fontSize: 15, fixed: true }); var txt = board.create('text', [4 * Math.PI - 0.5, -0.2, "720"], { fontSize: 15, fixed: true }); var txt = board.create('text', [-Math.PI -0.9, -0.2, "-180"], { fontSize: 15, fixed: true }); var txt = board.create('text', [-2 * Math.PI - 0.9, -0.2, "-360"], { fontSize: 15, fixed: true }); var txt = board.create('text', [-3 * Math.PI - 0.9, -0.2, "-540"], { fontSize: 15, fixed: true }); var txt = board.create('text', [{#angrad-0.2#}, -0.25, {#angdeg#}], { fontSize: 15, fixed: true }); var p1 = board.create('point',[{#angrad#}, 0], {name:'',size:2, fixed: true}); var p2 = board.create('point',[{#angrad#}, {#yval#}], {name:'',size:2, fixed: true}); var vertline = board.create('line', [[{#angrad#}, 0],[{#angrad#}, {#yval#}]], {straightFirst: false,straightLast: false,strokeWidth: 2,fixed:true}); var horline = board.create('line', [[0, {#yval#}],[1, {#yval#}]], {straightFirst: true,straightLast: true,strokeWidth: 2,fixed:true}); [[/jsxgraph]]

Find three other angles in the range \(-540 < x < 720\) which have the same value of \({@fx@}\) as \(x={@angdeg@}\).

\(x=\) [[input:ans1]] or [[input:ans2]] or [[input:ans3]]

[[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans2]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

[[ if test="fx = sin(x) "]]

In this case, we have \(x ={@angdeg@} \) and we need to find three other angles that have the same value of \(\sin(x)\) in the given range.

The three other angles can be calculated as follows:

1. \(x_1 = 360 + {@angdeg@} = {@ta1@}\)

2. \(x_2 = {@angdeg@} - 360 = {@ta2@}\)

3. \(x_3 = 180-{@angdeg@} = {@ta3@}\)

Therefore, the three angles in the range \(-540 < x < 720\) that have the same value of \(\sin(x)\) as \(x = {@angdeg@}\) are:

\(x = {@ta1@}\) or \(x = {@ta2@}\) or \(x = {@ta3@}\)

[[ elif test="fx = cos(x) "]]

In this case, we have \(x = {@angdeg@}\) and we need to find three other angles that have the same value of \(\cos(x)\) in the given range.

The three other angles can be calculated as follows:

1. \(x_1 = 360 + {@angdeg@} = {@ta1@}\)

2. \(x_2 = {@angdeg@} - 360 = {@ta2@}\)

3. \(x_3 = {@-angdeg@}= {@ta3@}\)

Therefore, the three angles in the range \(-540 < x < 720\) that have the same value of \(\cos(x)\) as \(x = {@angdeg@}\) are:

\(x = {@ta1@}\) or \(x = {@ta2@}\) or \(x = {@ta3@}\)

[[ elif test="fx =tan(x) "]]

In this case, we have \(x = {@angdeg@}\) and we need to find three other angles that have the same value of \(\tan(x)\) in the given range.

The three other angles can be calculated as follows:

1. \(x_1 = 180 + {@angdeg@} = {@ta1@}\)

2. \(x_2 = {@angdeg@} - 180 = {@ta2@}\)

3. \(x_3 = x_1 + 180= {@ta1@} + 180 = {@ta3@}\)

Therefore, the three angles in the range \(-540 < x < 720\) that have the same value of \(\tan(x)\) as \(x = {@angdeg@}\) are:

\(x = {@ta1@}\) or \(x = {@ta2@}\) or \(x = {@ta3@}\)

[[ else ]]

Invalid function. Please check the function \({@fx@}\) and try again.

[[/ if ]]

questionnote.text:
the trigonometric function \(y=f(x)={@fx@}\)

Angle point on the graph \(x = {@angdeg@}\)

The three other angles are:

\(x={@ta1@} \) or \(x={@ta2@}\) or \(x={@ta3@}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text: Some of your answers do not have the same value of \({@fx@}\) as \(x={@angdeg@}\).
You need three distinct answers. Use the symmetry in the graph to find more possible solutions within the range.

truefeedback.text: You included the angle \(x = {@angdeg@}\), which should not be included as an answer.

Hints:

The graphs have a lot of symmetry and you can use it, together with the horizontal line shown in the graph, to find as many solutions as needed.

In the case of \(f(x)=\sin(x)\), the period is 360 degrees so adding 360 to {@angdeg@} as many times as needed should give you a right answer. Also, we can use the symmetry between 0 and 180 degrees. By looking at the graph we see that there are two possible angles (\({@angdeg@}\) and a second one) shown by the intersections between the graph and the horizontal line. Due to the symmetry, we can see that the second angle should be \(x = 180-{@angdeg@} = {@180-angdeg@}\).

Hints:

The graphs have a lot of symmetry and you can use it, together with the horizontal line shown in the graph, to find as many solutions as needed.

In the case of \(f(x)=\cos(x)\), the period is 360 degrees so adding 360 to {@angdeg@} as many times as needed should give you a right answer. Also, we can use the symmetry between 0 and 360 degrees. By looking at the graph we see that there are two possible angles (\({@angdeg@}\) and a second one) shown by the intersections between the graph and the horizontal line. Due to the symmetry, we can see that the second angle should be \(x = 360-{@angdeg@} = {@360-angdeg@}\).

Hints:

The graphs have a lot of symmetry and you can use it, together with the horizontal line shown in the graph, to find as many solutions as needed.

In the case of \(f(x)=\tan(x)\), the period is 180 degrees so adding 180 to {@angdeg@} as many times as needed should give you the right answers. This can be evidenced in the graph as the intersections between the graph and the horizontal line repeat every 180 degrees.
